verb.description: Compress (something) into small folds or ridges.
examples: she crimped the edge of the pie

verb.description: Have a limiting or adverse effect on (something)
examples: farmers complain that the drought could crimp their income potential

noun.description: A curl, wave, or folded or compressed edge.
examples: this cascade of delicate crimps depends on a perm
the wool had too much crimp to be used in weaving
the crimp on take-home pay has been even tighter since taxes were raised

phrases: well, that puts a crimp in my theory
Hopefully the delay won't put a crimp in the supply.
In addition to the modest increase in demand, higher freight costs could put a crimp in cement imports, which account for about one-fifth of the market.
All in all, more than half of our contractors found that they had basically outgrown their trailer capacity before they'd planned to, putting a crimp in operations.
Tobacco also puts a crimp in your campaign against blood fats.
origin: Old English gecrympan, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch krimpen shrink, wrinkle. Of rare occurrence before the 18th century, the word was perhaps reintroduced from Low German or Dutch.
